ResponsesInList.Title: Global timeout even though maxtime was not even nearly obtained
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello. I am teaching a basic programming course and I use VPL for my evaluations. Most questions are fairly simple and can be solved in a few miliseconds, so I randomly create 100 test cases and assign a grade according to how many of them are correctly solved. Most questions take one or two seconds to be graded in this manner (or at least this is how long it takes after I click on the "evaluate" button). However, the "Maximum execution time" is not respected. Here's a MRE: There are 128 test cases, all equal to Case = Test input = 1 output = 1 Solution (in C) is #include <stdio.h> int main() { printf("1"); return 0; } It takes about 2 seconds to compile and 1 to evaluate, when it works. Maximum memory is 512MB, maximum execution files 128MB and maximum processes is 10. When I set up Maximum execution time to 8 minutes or more, it evaluates as above; However, anything below that yields "Global timeout". Some VPLs which I created evaluate in 4 minutes, others 2. I couldn't find a pattern. IT in my uni noticed that vpl_evaluate.cpp ( https://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/releases/vpl_evaluate.cpp ) has these lines: int timeout = maxtime / testCases.size(); for (size_t i = 0; i < testCases.size(); i++) { //... if (timeout <= 1 || Timer::elapsedTime() >= maxtime) { //... addFatalError("Global timeout"); and that maxtime = maximum time in seconds (integer). So if maxtime < testCases.size() we automatically get a "Global timeout" error, and this might be related to this issue. However, it does not explain why it does not evaluate in 4 minutes. So, I always have to set up a relatively high maximum execution time in order for correct answers to be properly evaluated (4 or 8 minutes, usually), even if they are actually evaluated basically instantly. However, whenever a student makes a nonending loop, they have to way for that whole time (4+ minutes) in order to get the timeout error message and be able to try again. This hinders VPLs usability in exams, which are time-sensitive. Is there anything I can do to mitigate this problem as a professor (no access to uni server and moodle plugin configs)? Or is there anything I could indicate IT to do? I note that this problem was already noticed in https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=451871&lang=en . Thank you very much.

ResponsesInList.Title: Global timeout even though maxtime was not even nearly obtained
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Luiz, Thank you for reporting this issue, and sorry for the inconvenience youâ€™re experiencing. You are correct â€” the BIOTES evaluator represents time limits as integer seconds and distributes the total maximum execution time among all test cases. Specifically, the timeout for each case is calculated approximately as: `timeout_per_case = maxtime / number_of_cases` Because of this design, if the number of test cases is large and the total time limit is not proportionally higher, the timeout for each individual case may become too small, causing a â€œGlobal timeoutâ€ error even when the total execution time seems reasonable. To avoid this, you should ensure that the maximum execution time is greater than the number of test cases . The more test cases you have, the larger this global time limit needs to be. Better Solution: Use the GIOTES Evaluator This limitation has been resolved in the newer GIOTES evaluator (VPL version >= 4.3.0), which is mostly compatible with BIOTES but provides much more flexibility in timeout management. With GIOTES , you can: Define a default timeout per test case using "time limit=" before any case, Override the timeout for specific cases using "time limit=" in the case, and Use floating-point values for more precise time limits (e.g., 0.5 seconds). This allows you to manage large numbers of test cases efficiently without artificially inflating the total maximum time. Server Configuration Note Be aware that the jail server configuration can also limit the maximum execution time.
By default, the jail serverâ€™s global timeout is 1800 seconds (30 minutes) , but this can be freely adjusted by the jail server administrator. In most cases, the default settings work well. However, reducing the number of allowed processes too much can negatively affect performance and lead to unexpected timeouts, so I would recommend keeping the default or slightly increasing it rather than lowering it. Best regards

ResponsesInList.Title: vpl cuda sopport
ResponsesInList.Text: hello, one of our professors wants to use the vpl for his deep learning courses. so, i wanted to know if vpl supports cuda/ servers with gpu capabilities.

ResponsesInList.Title: vpl cuda sopport
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, VPL is a two-part solution. The first part sits on the server and runs the code in a sandbox environment. Thus, if we want to run a specific package of, let us say, Python, then if the computer that has the VPL server running can compile Python, and has the package available and correctly configured, the code sent to it will run, and you will have an output. The Moodle plugin facilitates sending the code to the server; thus, instead of the professor downloading the student code to their development machine, executing the code, and viewing the results, the plugin does this work. There is also a way to automate checking. If the professor spends a little time, higher automation in the evaluation of the results is possible. This summarises the workflow. Now, to address your query: The sandbox environment should also have access to the GPUs. There is work to be done under the hood, however, if there is experience in setting up GPUs on another machine of similar architecture, it should be a cinch. Extensive testing is required to fully understand the workflow. Process execution limits should be suitable for the proposed workload. Very few institutions will run the backend jobe server on GPU and CUDA capable servers, although it is possible. We are curious to now the outcome and welcome the experience of your team and the professor's success in this interesting, relevant and emerging learning direction.

ResponsesInList.Title: executable server not found
ResponsesInList.Text:
When VPL tries to locate an available execution server for your request, it checks whether each server has enough free memory to satisfy the maximum memory limit defined in the activity configuration. If the required memory exceeds either the maximum memory allowed in the Jail Server configuration or the currently available free memory on that server, the request will not be assigned to that server. To resolve this issue, please verify: The maximum memory limit configured for each request in your Jail Server setup:
ðŸ”— Jail Server configuration â€“ maxMemory The maximum memory used in the activity configuration:
ðŸ”— Activity configuration â€“ execution resource limits If the activityâ€™s requested memory is higher than what each Jail Server allows or whatâ€™s currently available, the system will report â€œno execution server found.â€

ResponsesInList.Title: python simple hello fails - log states Compilation fail
ResponsesInList.Text: Please note that the VPL Jail Server must be accessible from the internet because the userâ€™s browser connects directly to it when running activities . Also, modern browsers block access to non-secure resources ( `http` or `ws` ) when the main Moodle site is loaded over a secure connection ( `https` ). This means that if your Moodle server uses `https` , the browser will prevent access to a VPL Jail Server that uses `http` or `ws` . To resolve this, you should configure your VPL Jail Server using a public IP and `https` . This ensures compatibility with browsersâ€™ security requirements and allows proper communication of browsers and the Jail Server.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The reason for this is that there are two separate steps for execution: preparation and actual execution. This allows teachers to better customize the way they want to evaluate submissions (such as compiling, cleaning, generating tests, etc.). So yes, you need to create an executable "vpl_execution" file, which will then be executed. The latter execution is the one that should echo the grade.

Hi Andrew and Garth, Thank you for your detailed message and for testing VPL with R on the Docker-based jail server. Iâ€™ve tried to reproduce your issue using the Docker image `jcrodriguezvpl/jail-ubuntu-full` , but so far, I havenâ€™t encountered the same problem. The message you're seeing â€” `Error constructing proxy for org.gnome.Terminal` â€” appears to be related not to VPL itself, but to the containerâ€™s graphical environment or its resource constraints. Running R in VPL 4.3.2 With the release of VPL 4.3.2 , we have simplified R integration by using VPLâ€™s new running modes . These allow better control over how R scripts are executed, especially in text mode or GUI terminal environments. As you may know, the R tool is based on a REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop) interface, which complicates direct integration with VPL. After exploring various approaches, the latest solution uses `Rscript` , which is better suited for automated/scripted execution. Here's how R execution works using Rscript in VPL 4.3.2: The first `.R` file in the student submission is run using `Rscript --vanilla` . Since `Rscript` is not interactive, you need to: Use `readLines(file("stdin"), n = 1)` to read input. To display charts: Save them as image files using `png("file.png")` or `jpeg("file.jpg")` .
Generate the image, chart, etc.
Close the graphics device using `dev.off()` .
Show the image with an external viewer using: 
```text
r
   system("nohup xdg-open file.png &")
```
 (Note: This need a text in GUI run mode) Suggested Setup (if not using VPL 4.3.2) If you're not yet on VPL 4.3.2, you can configure R execution manually by using the following `vpl_run.sh` script in "execution files" for text-only mode : 
```text
#!/bin/bash
# Script for running R in VPL
. common_script.sh
check_program R
get_first_source_file r R
cat common_script.sh > vpl_execution
echo "Rscript --vanilla \"$FIRST_SOURCE_FILE\"" >> vpl_execution
chmod +x vpl_execution
```
 To run in a GUI terminal (text in GUI mode) , you may add to the previous vpl_run.sh: 
```text
mv vpl_execution vpl_execution_in_gui
cat common_script.sh > vpl_wexecution
cat <<'END_SCRIPT' >> vpl_wexecution
if command -v gnome-terminal &> /dev/null; then
    gnome-terminal -- bash -c "./vpl_execution_in_gui; echo; read -p 'Press Enter to continue...'"
elif command -v xterm &> /dev/null; then
    xterm -e bash -c "./vpl_execution_in_gui; echo; read -p 'Press Enter to continue...'"
elif command -v konsole &> /dev/null; then
    konsole --noclose -e "./vpl_execution_in_gui"
elif command -v xfce4-terminal &> /dev/null; then
    xfce4-terminal --hold --command="./vpl_execution_in_gui"
else
    echo "No terminal emulator found. Running without GUI terminal."
    ./vpl_execution_in_gui
fi
wait_end vpl_execution_in_gui
END_SCRIPT
chmod +x vpl_wexecution
```
 Best regards,
Juan Carlos RodrÃ­guez

Dear Amit Singh, After a examination of the issue you've described, it appears the cause is linked to the configuration of the NODE_PATH environment variable. This variable allows Node.js to locate global modules, including the `readline-sync` module your script depends on. To address this problem and ensure your JavaScript code executes in VPL, a temporary solution can be implemented until the upcoming VPL release, which will include an automatic configuration of the NODE_PATH variable. Here is an enhanced script for your `vpl_run.sh` file. This script sets up the NODE_PATH variable and prepare the run of your JavaScript code. 
```text
#!/bin/bash
# This file is part of VPL for Moodle - 
http://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/

# Script for JavaScript language using NodeJs
# Copyright (C) 2024 Juan Carlos RodrÃ­guez-del-Pino
# License 
http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html
 GNU GPL v3 or later
# Author Juan Carlos RodrÃ­guez-del-Pino <jcrodriguez@dis.ulpgc.es>

# @vpl_script_description Using nodejs with the first file
# load common script and check programs
. common_script.sh
check_program nodejs
if [ "$1" == "version" ] ; then
    get_program_version -v
fi

get_first_source_file js
cat common_script.sh > vpl_execution
[ "$(command -pv npm)" != "" ] && (echo "export NODE_PATH=$(npm root -g)" >> vpl_execution)
echo "nodejs \"$FIRST_SOURCE_FILE\" \$@" >> vpl_execution
chmod +x vpl_execution
```

ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Giuseppe, Thanks for your message. I understand that when you mention "I have set VPL to listen on port 8443 HTTPS and 8080 HTTP", you are referring to the VPL Jail System . Just to clarify, installing the VPL Jail System on a VPS is not the most typical setup. If accessing `http://server:8282/OK` returns â€œOKâ€, then the VPL Jail System is likely running correctly. However, there may be a small typo: based on your earlier message, I believe the correct port should be `8080` , not `8282` . Assuming your Moodle site is using the default ports (80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS), here are a few key points and recommendations to help you troubleshoot the timeout issue: Checklist to verify configuration Verify the ports Double-check the port numbers youâ€™ve configured, both in the VPL Jail System and in the Moodle VPL plugin. Use full external URL In the Moodle VPL plugin configuration, ensure you're using the full external URL (e.g., `https://your-domain:8443` ). Do not use `localhost` here, note that this URL is send to the browser to access the VPL-Jail-System. Check HTTPS functionality Make sure you can access `https://your-domain:8443/OK` . This will confirm that the VPL Jail System is properly serving over HTTPS. URLPATH security It is highly recommended to configure the `URLPATH` parameter in the VPL Jail System. This adds a layer of security by ensuring only authorized Moodle servers can access it. Self-signed certificate setting Since you are using a valid Let's Encrypt certificate, the "accept self-signed certificates" option in the Moodle plugin should be disabled . Reverse proxy and WebSocket support If you're using a reverse proxy to expose the VPL Jail System, ensure it supports WebSocket connections . Note that the `/OK` endpoint does not use WebSockets, so its success does not guarantee that task execution will work properly. Remove unnecessary HTTP port If you're not using HTTP on port 8080, consider disabling it to reduce attack surface and potential misconfiguration. Let me know if you continue to experience issues after these checks. Weâ€™ll be happy to help further. Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SPIM MIPS32 assembler
ResponsesInList.Text:
To enable SPIM MIPS32 assembler code execution in VPL, you need to install the `spim` package on your VPL Jail Server . Installation Steps: For Debian, Ubuntu, and related distributions: 
```text
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install spim
sudo systemctl restart vpl-jail-system
```
 For Fedora and similar distributions: 
```text
sudo dnf install spim
sudo systemctl restart vpl-jail-system
```
 Restarting the `vpl-jail-service` ensures that the newly installed software is recognized within the VPL jail environment. For further details on configuring execution servers, refer to the VPL Jail Server documentation .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQLite now outputting version information and shell prompt
ResponsesInList.Text: After some digging, and some clear help from Chat, here's the changes that forced sqlite3 out of non-interactive mode and got rid of the version information: 1. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SQLite now outputting version information and shell prompt
ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Garth Brady, Thank you for reporting this issue and for your investigation into its cause. For many years, the run of `sql_run.sh` execution script for SQLite3 generate a code to go in interactive mode showing the software version. However, it seems that now also shows the version when VPL is evaluating the student code. Upcoming Fix: In the next VPL release, we plan to modify the sql_run.sh script to suppress the SQLite3 version output when in the evaluation process. Workaround: In the meantime, to resolve the problem, you can customize your `vpl_run.sh` (based on `sql_run.sh` from the VPL source) . For example, modify the code block that checks for batch mode. Instead of: 
```text
if [ "$1" != "batch" ]; then
    echo "sqlite3 $DBFILE" >> vpl_execution
fi
```
 you can change it to: 
```text
if [ "$1" != "batch" ]; then
   if [ -f vpl_evaluate.sh ]; then
       BATCHOPTION="-batch"
   fi
   echo "sqlite3 $BATCHOPTION $DBFILE" >> vpl_execution
fi
```
 If you wish to avoid going in interactive mode of SQLite3 when running use: 
```text
if [ "$1" != "batch" ]; then
   echo "sqlite3 -batch $DBFILE" >> vpl_execution
fi
```
 Thanks again for your valuable feedback. Please let us know if you have any further questions or suggestions. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: VPL auto grading and custom evaluation
ResponsesInList.Text: Basically, vpl_evaluate.sh is first executed and its goal is to produce an executable named `vpl_execution` . At this point, every execution files and submitted files are available. Then the VPL clears all execution files from the environment, and executes the `vpl_execution` file. At this point, in the environment, you would find submitted files, `vpl_execution` , `common_script.sh` , and any file generated by the first phase. If you need an execution file to be present during this second execution phase, you need to check it in the "Files to keep when running" menu. Here I suggest this because python is interpreted, but for a compiled language, you would typically compile your `vpl_evaluate.xxx` then you can freely use the generated executable. Or even better name that executable directly `vpl_execution` !

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Interactive Shell / Mode ? in VPL
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Rajasekaran S, From VPL version 4.1.1, there is a "Run script" option called COMMAND-LINE . By selecting this option in the execution options settings page, users can utilize VPL to edit files and maintain a persistent text terminal session that allows interaction with the execution environment. While the execution session is active, any saved files are continuously updated in the execution environment. Please note that files created or modified directly within the text terminal are not saved back to the VPL environment. The file synchronization only works from the VPL environment to the execution environment, but not in reverse. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Errors after upgrading to Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Jacob Tate, Thank you for your detailed issue report. I have not been able to replicate the problem. Please note that the demojail server has been running on Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS for two years without exhibiting this issue. Regarding the unusual correlation between the problem and the settings in `/etc/profile` , these settings should only affect bash behavior for the user, not script execution. About `$2` in `vpl_run.sh` The second script argument ( `$2` ) in the execution scripts for different programming languages is specifically intended for passing additional parameters to the compilation or interpretation command. In the C and C++ execution script , `$2` is currently used by the debugger preparation script to compile the program with debugging information ( `-g` ) and no optimization ( `-O0` ). The current VPL execution server does not add extra parameters when executing `vpl_run.sh` . Next Steps From your report, it appears that you modified `vpl_run.sh` . To further investigate: 1. Could you provide the full content of your `vpl_run.sh` file? 2. If you are using the VPL "based on" feature , please also share the inherited files. Temporary Workaround Since you are not using the debugging button , a simple and safe workaround is to remove `$2` from the compilation command in `vpl_run.sh` for the affected activity. This should prevent unintended arguments from being passed to `gcc` . Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there really no way to prevent external access for VPL Servers? It seems awfully short sighted to allow arbitrary code execution open to the entire internet. Short of whitelisting VPL Users at an external firewall is there really no easy way to secure this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Jacob, to secure VPL execution servers and prevent external access, you can: Use HTTPS with the appropriate certificates. Configure the `URLPATH` parameter in the execution servers. This acts as a secret key only known to the administrator, ensuring that only requests with the correct `URLPATH` are served. Set the `TASK_ONLY_FROM` parameter, which allows you to define a whitelist of IP addresses without relying on an external firewall. You can find detailed instructions on implementing these security measures at VPL Documentation - Security Parameters .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Jacob, The `URLPATH` configuration parameter is solely utilized during the execution task requests between the Moodle server and the execution server. This â€œpasswordâ€ is neither required nor accessible from the user's browser in any form. Communication between the user's browser and the execution server is protected through single-use tickets generated by the execution server for each execution. The concerns about data leakage from browser plugins or indexers do not apply to URLPATH, as it is never exposed outside the server-to-server communication. It is important to base security discussions on a clear understanding of how these mechanisms work. If you have further technical questions or need clarifications, feel free to reach out. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Protecting VPL Servers
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't see a clear advantage in using separate ports for task requests and WebSocket connections. WebSocket connections are secured using HTTPS and switch to WebSocket protocols, ensuring robust encryption. Additionally, many organizations aim to minimize the number of open ports to streamline security management. Regarding your concern about system administrators potentially being unaware of the risks of omitting the `URLPATH` parameter, future releases of VPL will address this. We will introduce warnings in the execution server startup process and in the VPL plugin's execution server checks. These warnings will explicitly highlight the risks of not using `URLPATH` and strongly recommend its configuration to enhance security.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: pygame or turtle graphics in VPL
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Rajasekaran, Thank you for your query regarding the execution of Pygame or Turtle programs in VPL. Let me clarify how VPL determines the execution environment for programs and provide some guidance. The current version of VPL automatically selects the execution environment (text terminal, GUI, or web) based on criteria specific to each programming language. Unfortunately, manual selection of the execution environment is not yet supported. However, this feature is planned for a future VPL release. For now, the execution environment is determined by the type of executable file produced during compilation phase: vpl_execution for text terminal, vpl_wexecution for GUI, vpl_webexecution for web. Workarounds To run your code in the desired environment, you can use one of the following workarounds: Modify the Execution Script: Copy the default execution script for your programming language from the VPL source into a file named `vpl_run.sh` in the execution files section of your activity. Edit the script to rename the executable file produced during compilation (e.g., from `vpl_execution` to `vpl_wexecution` ). For Python Programs: If your program requires a GUI environment, you can "cheat" the execution script by including a reference to `Tkinter` in your source code (e.g., adding a comment like `# Tkinter` ). This triggers the script to use a GUI execution environment. These methods should allow you to successfully run Pygame or Turtle programs in VPL. Please note that additional adjustments may be needed depending on the specifics of your program or setup. Best regards, Juan Carlos

The current VPL-Jail- Server launchers use the default VNC server of the Linux distribution they are running on. Regarding your observation, the RANDR (Resize and Rotate) extension is indeed essential for dynamic resizing of display outputs and screen resolution changes. From what I understand, TightVNC does not support the RANDR extension. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recursion causes the browser to hang
ResponsesInList.Text: I attempted to reproduce the issue you're facing but was unsuccessful. You did not mention the version of VPL you are using, but based on the screenshot, it appears you're on the "Submission view" page, trying to display the evaluation report. A similar bug was fixed in VPL version 3.5, where an inefficient regular expression (regex) caused issues when rendering evaluation reports. If you are using an outdated version of VPL, I recommend updating to the latest release, as this might resolve the problem. As a workaround for the current issue, you can go directly to the Submission page (not the "Submission view" page). You can access the Submission page by copying the URL from another user who is able to view it, and then ask the student to submit a new version without the circular dependency. Once the student submits a corrected version, the submission should display correctly, and the issue will be resolved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recursion causes the browser to hang
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for sharing the code. I was able to reproduce the issue you're experiencing. When the circular dependency occurs, the compilation process generates over 14,000 lines of error messages. VPL tries to automatically link each of these lines to the corresponding line in the source code. This linking process is handled by the browser, which struggles to manage such a large number of lines efficiently. This may be due to an inefficient regular expression or poor string handling in the JavaScript responsible for this task. I am marking this issue as a bug, and it will be addressed in a future release of the VPL plugin. In the meantime, you might consider advising students to avoid circular dependencies or reviewing the code before submission to prevent such issues from occurring. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Anyone succeeded with nginx subfolder reverse proxy configuration?
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear wz, I believe that the current URL schema used to interact with the VPL Jail Server does not support the use of subfolder paths when placed behind an reverse proxy. This limitation is due to the way the VPL Jail Server URLs are structured. While this could be addressed in the future to provide more flexibility in how the VPL Jail Server is configured, it is not a high priority at the moment. For a workaround, I recommend using an alias name for the Nginx server instead of a subfolder. The alias name can redirect requests to the VPL Jail Server, allowing you to place the VPL jail server machine (with other name and IP) behind the Nginx server while keeping the current URL schema intact. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: VPL Docker Containers - Setup
ResponsesInList.Text: Dr. S. Rajasekaran, Thank you for sharing your experience with VPL. Details are important for understanding the behavior and performance of VPL. Could you please indicate if you have tested adding more Jail servers to your Moodle server to resolve the performance issues and what resources (especially RAM) the machines you added have available? Using one machine for both the Moodle server and the Jail Server may raise some inconveniences. You must limit the resources available for the Jail Server to avoid slowing down Moodle when the jail server gets very bussy. Remember to set the correct URL (reachable from the internet) for the jail server in the VPL plugin configuration. Note that if you use localhost or the localhost IP (127.X:X:X) for your jail server it will only be available from a browser on that machine. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Regex not working on vpl_cases
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Bruna, It seems like the issue is related to the use of the backslash "" in your regex. In programming laguages strings, the backslash is used as an escape character to represent special characters in a string, such as "
" for newline and "	" for tab. When using regex, backslashes are also used to escape special regex characters to treat them as literal characters, for example, "\." to match a dot instead of any character. However, in VPL regex, the first use of the backslash (for special characters like "

". Please try replacing your "
" with an actual newline character in your expressions. Note that the "output=" option in VPL allows for multilines. Additionally, using regex can sometimes be complex and may require external tools to identify discrepancies. Simplifying the expected output of student's code, using simpler regex patterns or other types of expected output as numbers or text may ease the process of writing test cases and improve readability.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to delete (reset) student submission
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Nadav Kavalerchik, The behavior of the VPL (Virtual Programming Lab) is different from that of the Assignment module. In the VPL, there is no distinction between draft and final submissions. A student can upload or modify their work as many times as they want until the due date, including versions that have already been assessed. Before the due date, students can continue to modify their submissions. Typically, teachers assess the student's work after the due date. If a student has uploaded a submission by mistake, they can still modify or replace it before the due date without needing any additional permissions. Best regards, Juan Carlos

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to upgrade the node version in jail server
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Amit Singh, It's important to note that the jail server installer typically installs, using the local package manager, the latest versions of development software stock available in the Linux distribution you are using. This include npm, used, and nodejs. However, you have the flexibility to use any version of the development software on your jail server. The key limitation is ensuring that the command line interface of the software version you choose is compatible with the scripts used by the VPL (Virtual Programming Lab) plugin. Specifically regarding your query, the npm command is utilized by the jail server installer exclusively for installing Node.js packages. Meanwhile, the Node.js command is employed by the VPL plugin's JavaScript runner. Both commands rely on straightforward command line interfaces, which means you should encounter no issues when updating or downgrading these pieces of software. Regarding updating Node.js to a version that is compatible with npm 10.4.0, as you've described the requirement ^18.17.0 || >=20.5.0, it can be accomplished in the usual manner and with the standard precautions associated with software updates. Please note, this process is independent of the VPL jail server's specific considerations.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Securing vpl-jail-system on a production LAMP server [RESOLVED]
ResponsesInList.Text:
To summarize the findings of a synchronous session with Nimal : - Modern browsers don't allow a vpl-jail-system to run purely on HTTP. The first response from the service contains a password, the browser automatically switches to HTTPS because of this. - vpl-jail-system will run if you configure a HTTPS port too, say 8080 for HTTP and 8443 for HTTPS, provided that the SSL certificate is recognized by the browser. It works with a self-signed certificate, if user accept it once following the pop-up attached below. P.S. I see the Note on https://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/documentation/vpl-jail-system-3.0.1/installation.html#getting-vpl-jail-system === If you have your own SSL certificates for the HTTPS and WSS communications,
you must copy your public certificate to the â€œ/etc/vpl/cert.pemâ€ file and the
private key to the â€œ/etc/vpl/key.pemâ€ file. You also can change the configuration
file to tell the system the location of your certificates. If your Certification
Authority (CA) is not a root CA you may need to add the intermediate CA certificates
to the â€œcert.pemâ€ file. You may restart the service to apply the modifications. === I don't know whether it tells the whole story.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Securing vpl-jail-system on a production LAMP server [RESOLVED]
ResponsesInList.Text: > - Modern browsers don't allow a vpl-jail-system to run purely on HTTP. The first response from the service contains a password, the > browser automatically switches to HTTPS because of this. It looked like it was not a decision of the browser, but the javascript code requires / uses HTTPS for /monitor and /execute operations. Because we had SECURE PORT set to 0, the browser could not proceed. So my conclusion would be that vpl-jail-system requires HTTPS, and if you set SECURE PORT to 0 things break. Documentation should clearly say that listening on HTTPS is mandatory.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Securing vpl-jail-system on a production LAMP server [RESOLVED]
ResponsesInList.Text: Update (after further experimentation with Visvanath ) Confirmed that it is indeed the browser making the decision not to use ws over HTTP. In firefox, it is possible to overwrite this default setting by going to about:config and setting network.websocket.allowInsecureFromHTTPS to true (default value is false). ResponsesInList.Title: Re: php modules not loaded
ResponsesInList.Text: The issue you're encountering, where the PHP JSON extension appears to be loaded in the command line (CLI) environment but not in a web server or script execution context , is not uncommon. This often occurs due to differences in PHP configurations between the CLI and the web server environments. PHP often uses different php.ini files for the CLI and web server environments. To verify which php.ini file is being used by your web server, create a PHP file with the following content and access it via a browser: <?php phpinfo(); ?>

To address the "Http(s) Unsupported METHOD CONNECT" error, let's break it down: The check you mentioned pertains to WebSocket connections' URL paths. These connections originate from the user's browser. The error message "Http(s) Unsupported METHOD CONNECT" indicates that either your browser or a proxy in your network is attempting to send a CONNECT method request to the Jail server. The CONNECT method is typically used by proxies but doesn't make sense for the Jail server. To resolve this issue, consider the following steps: Verify your network configuration: Ensure that there are no misconfigured proxies in your network that might be causing this issue. Use a full transparent proxy: If necessary, set up a transparent proxy that doesn't interfere with WebSocket connections. Direct connection to the Jail server: If feasible, try connecting directly to the Jail server without any intermediate proxies to see if the issue persists. I hope this helps you diagnose and resolve the problem effectively. Best regards,
Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating Python graded activity on VPL to evaluate dynamic output
ResponsesInList.Text:
The issue you are facing stems from the fact that VPL attempts to run the source file as is, which may not work without the proper file permissions and, in Python, the inclusion of a shebang line as the first code line (e.g., `#!/bin/python3` ). It's worth noting that, currently, the evaluation program does not automatically adjust file permissions before running a program. Introducing this feature into the evaluation program should be carefully considered due to potential security implications. In this particular case, it seems that you may not need to use the "program to run =" option to execute the student's code. If you remove this line from your configuration, VPL should run the student's code for the test case without requiring any additional configuration. However, if you still wish to use the "program to run =" option, you can run the student's code by invoking the Python interpreter and specifying the student's file as an argument. You can achieve this by configuring the following settings: Program to run = /bin/python3 Program arguments = chkDate.py For more detailed information, you can refer to the VPL documentation at https://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/documentation/vpl-3.4.3+/biotes.html . I hope this guidance helps you resolve the evaluation issue with your Python activity on VPL. Best regards,
Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Text: In response to your query regarding the maximum memory limit in the VPL environment, it's important to note that there isn't a strict hard limit imposed. However, it's crucial to understand that there are three distinct levels of resource limits to consider: VPL Execution Server Level: The first level of resource limitation is at the VPL execution server. You can configure resource limits at this level, and details on how to do so can be found in the official documentation here: VPL Execution Server Configuration . Moodle Plugin Configuration Level: The second level involves setting resource limits at the Moodle level through plugin configuration. You can explore the necessary configurations in the plugin's global settings. Refer to this link for more information: Moodle Plugin Configuration . VPL Activity Level: Finally, the third level of resource limits is at the VPL activity level within the activity settings. It's important to understand that the most restrictive limit among these three levels will be applied when executing VPL activities . You can find additional details on this level of configuration here: VPL Activity Level Configuration . In summary, while there isn't a fixed hard limit for memory allocation, the resource limits imposed by the three levels mentioned above collectively determine the maximum memory available. To extend this limit, you should carefully adjust these configurations as per your requirements, keeping in mind that the most restrictive setting will take precedence.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: back and forth between server and submission
ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Garth Brady, I appreciate your active involvement in the VPL forum. Thank you for your contributions. To address your query regarding the back-and-forth communication: While VPL doesn't support this directly, it is flexible enough to facilitate your approach with some adjustments. To achieve this, you will need to modify the `vpl_run.sh` script. The goal is to generate an executable named either `vpl_execution` or `vpl_wexecution`. In this context , the executable will be a bash script. Within this bash script, you should set up two programs, one for posing questions (`ask`) and another for responding (`answer`). Additionally, you must create two named pipes (FIFOs) to facilitate communication between these programs. Here's a basic outline: 
```text
mkfifo pipe1


mkfifo pipe2


ask   < pipe1 > pipe2 &


answer < pipe2 > pipe1
```
 Note that the entire program will conclude when the `answer` program finishes. I hope this provides a clear direction for your project. Please let me know if you have further questions. Kind regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle server with SSL (https) and VPL server without SSL (http)
ResponsesInList.Text: Your issue likely cannot be addressed solely by reconfiguring the Virtual Programming Lab (VPL). This is due to the inherent security measures in modern web browsers, which are disinclined to allow HTTP (non-SSL) connections from pages loaded via HTTPS. To remedy this situation, I would recommend securing all your servers with SSL certificates. You can obtain these certificates free of charge from Let's Encrypt, a non-profit certificate authority. Using Let's Encrypt will not only make your servers more secure but will also eliminate the browser restrictions you are currently encountering. Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Use VPL with large files
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Nicolas BODIN, I appreciate your interest in using VPL (Virtual Programming Lab) for your algorithms and abstract data types course. Thank you for bringing up your concerns regarding the page load speed and file saving behavior. I'd like to address each point: Slow Page Load for Showing Large Files: The delay you are experiencing is due to the system is interpreting unknown file types as code files, thus attempting to render them. Solution for Slow Page Load: To circumvent this issue, you can rename the files with a .bin extension. This will mark the files as binary, and the description page and editor will not attempt to display their content. To add these .bin files to the editor, you can use the drag-and-drop feature or the import functionality. Required vs. Execution Files: You don't necessarily need to add these large files to the "Required files" section. Adding them to the "Execution files" section and marking them as "Files to keep when running" will suffice for your purposes. File Saving Behavior: The editor, by design, saves all the files every time you execute a save command, regardless of whether a single file or multiple files have been modified. ResponsesInList.Title: å›žæ‡‰: Running OpenGL in VPL
ResponsesInList.Text:
Recently I have a similar issue on running OpenGL program in VPL and I would like to contribute my experimental solution. The workaround is to run the nested X server "Xephyr" and display the vpl_wexecution program to the nested window. Below is the steps for preparing the jail server: Install Xephyr (apt install xserver-xephyr) Modify /usr/sbin/vpl/vpl_vnc_launcher.sh, replace the line "$HOME/vpl_wexecution &> .std_output" with the following block 
```text
        if [ -f $HOME/.glx_required ]; then
          VNCDISPLAY=$(ls $HOME/.vnc/*.log | sed -e "s/[^:]*://" -e "s/\.log$//")
          XEPHYRDISP=$(($VNCDISPLAY+25000))
          Xephyr :$XEPHYRDISP -fullscreen &
          while true; do
            DISPLAY=:$XEPHYRDISP xdpyinfo >& /dev/null
            [ "$?" == "0" ] && break
          done
          DISPLAY=:$XEPHYRDISP $HOME/vpl_wexecution &> .std_output
        else
          $HOME/vpl_wexecution &> .std_output
        fi
```
 For a VPL instance that requires GLX support In "Execution files" section, add an empty file called .glx_required In "Files to keep when running" section, tick .glx_required In "Resources limits", the option "Maximum memory used" should be at least 256MB In fact, the workaround is a preliminary work. It has been tested in single-user case (at least for my programs). I am not sure whether it works without trouble in multi-user case. Hope this would help in your case.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: VPL - how to add prisoners to secondary group(s)
ResponsesInList.Text:
It looks like I found a partial solution to my problem. Not sure about its safety, but seems to be working. The trick is to modify and recompile the vpl daemon C++ code so the user GID is always the same (2000 in my case). Technically no secondary group, but I get the group membership I need. Won't work if several groups per prisoner are needed. Procedure: Do all the steps on the installation page until this step . Stop before executing `install-script-sh` . OR simply `cd` to your `vpl-jail-system-[version]` directory you used for vpl jail installation. Find the following line: link `src/processMonitor.cpp` file `processMonitor::becomePrisoner(int prisoner)` method `setresgid` function ( `unistd.h` ) Modify the line: `if (setresgid(prisoner, prisoner, prisoner)!= 0) {` After modification (hard-coded gid=2000 in my case): `if (setresgid(2000, 2000, 2000)!= 0) {` Stop the daemon and backup config if you made any customizations: `sudo systemctl stop vpl-jail-system.service` `sudo systemctl disable vpl-jail-system.service` `` `sudo mv /usr/sbin/vpl /usr/sbin/vpl.backup` `sudo cp /etc/vpl/ /etc/vpl.backup` `sudo cp /etc/vpl/vpl-jail-system.conf /etc/vpl/vpl-jail-system.conf.backup` Re-run installation script in order to recompile the daemon (respond "no" to software & SSL key installation queries if you have them already installed): `sudo ./install-vpl-sh` Edit `/usr/sbin/vpl/vpl-jail-system` (fresh one was copied from `vpl-jail-system.initd` during the previous step). Diff is here: https://diffonline.net/1JZPOA982x Before: 
```text
function set_etc {
        #passwd file
        local PASSWORDFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/passwd"
        local I
        echo "root:*:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash" > "$PASSWORDFILE"
        for (( I=$MIN_PRISONER_UGID ; $I < $MAX_PRISONER_UGID ; I+=1 )) ; do
                echo "p$I:*:$I:$I:prisoner $I:/home/p$I:/bin/bash" >> "$PASSWORDFILE"
        done
        chmod 644 "$PASSWORDFILE"
        #group file
        local GROUPFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/group"
        echo "root:*:0:root" > "$GROUPFILE"
        for (( I=$MIN_PRISONER_UGID ; $I < $MAX_PRISONER_UGID ; I+=1 )) ; do
                echo "p$I:*:$I:p$I" >> "$GROUPFILE"
        done
        chmod 644 "$GROUPFILE"
        local SHADOWFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/shadow"
        chown root.root "$SHADOWFILE"
        chmod 600 "$SHADOWFILE"
}
```
 After (replace `mygroup` and `2000` as needed): 
```text
function set_etc {
        local MYGROUP="mygroup"
        local MYGROUPGUID="2000"
        #passwd file
        local PASSWORDFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/passwd"
        local I
        echo "root:*:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash" > "$PASSWORDFILE"
        for (( I=$MIN_PRISONER_UGID ; $I < $MAX_PRISONER_UGID ; I+=1 )) ; do
                echo "p$I:*:$I:$MYGROUPGUID:prisoner $I:/home/p$I:/bin/bash" >> "$PASSWORDFILE"
        done
        chmod 644 "$PASSWORDFILE"
        #group file
        local GROUPFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/group"
        echo "root:*:0:root" > "$GROUPFILE"
        echo "$MYGROUP:*:$MYGROUPGUID:" >> "$GROUPFILE"
        chmod 644 "$GROUPFILE"
        local SHADOWFILE="$JAILPATH/etc/shadow"
        chown root.root "$SHADOWFILE"
        chmod 600 "$SHADOWFILE"
}
```
 Note: it is another topic, but you may need to add `set_other /yourpath` in `start_vpl` function and `unset_other /yourpath` in `stop_vpl` function to be able to access custom-mounted filesystems in the jail. Restart the vpl jail service: `sudo systemctl restart vpl-jail-system.service` Result (in the browser): 
```text
+ id
uid=10005 gid=2000(mygroup) groups=2000(mygroup)

+ members mygroup
p10000 p10001 p10002 p10003 p10004

+ cat /etc/passwd
root:*:0:0:root:/root:/bin/bash
p10000:*:10000:2000:prisoner 10000:/home/p10000:/bin/bash
p10001:*:10001:2000:prisoner 10001:/home/p10001:/bin/bash
p10002:*:10002:2000:prisoner 10002:/home/p10002:/bin/bash
p10003:*:10003:2000:prisoner 10003:/home/p10003:/bin/bash
p10004:*:10004:2000:prisoner 10004:/home/p10004:/bin/bash

+ cat /etc/group
root:*:0:root
mygroup:*:2000:
```
 To summarize: I think this is a good enough temporary solution (although with ugly hardcoded gid) but I would be happy to know if it can be done better (or included as a feature in the next VPL Jail release) and about security issues The solution doesn't add prisoners to secondary group. It just sets common primary group for them. Is there any solution for prisoners to belong to several groups? I have no idea what is the purpose of `/etc/shadow` file in the jail context , since both `/jail/etc/shadow` and `/var/vpl-jail-system/jail_live/etc/shadow` contain host server users' info and not the prisoners' I think there is a small bug in the original `vpl-jail-system.initd` script. Result is similar to the one above: for `MAX_PRISONER_UGID=10005` , the user p10005 is not added in `$JAILPATH/etc/passwd` and `$JAILPATH/etc/group` . Only the users p10000-p10004 are added. ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, from VPL 4.0 the default running action for submissions with index.html (HTML) or index.php (PHP) files is running a web server on the execution machine and granting access to it to a browser on the user's machine. This feature reduces drastically the resources needed on the server and improves development possibilities. Also, this removes the compatibility problems due to the use of a VNC client. Improves and functionalities: - Speed up the task start process - When running, It is possible to edit the code and save, updating code in the execution server without restarting the task. - Do not close the text terminal, to close the text terminal stop the running task. Notice that you can move and change the size of the text terminal. - The text terminal shows the URLs that the browser requests. - For security reasons, teachers must run the web apps in a browser without credentials to access Moodle. To get this an easy action may be to right-click on the open link and select an incognito o private window. Another possibility is copying the URL on the open link and using it in another browser. - You can use the development tools of your favorite browser to debug HTML, CSS , JavaScript , etc. Best regrads, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: vpl 3.0.0 - Please, to access web applications use a new Private or Incognito window.
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Toom, after replaying the issue you show I spotted the problem. VPL uses the PHP built-in web server for running HTML and PHP. When the URL that you send to this web server points to a directory the web server searches for "index.php" or "index.html" inside the directory and served it if the file is found. Notice that the web server does not search for "index.htm". The URL send as the first request to the server is the user root directory "https://servername/". To resolve the issue you must use "index.html" as the starting page name and not "index.htm". I don't know if it will be better to use a URL to the first (htm|html) file as the first request. The screenshot that you show indicates you are using VPL plugin version 4.0.1, the last version so far, and the message you get from the execution server that you are using a VPL execution server version 2.8 or higher (maybe 3.0.0). Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Text:
I cannot find a detailed, public documentation for this... So, here is a short explaination of what I know :D The files that you will edit are the ones in Execution Files: `vpl_run.sh` (for Run action), `vpl_debug.sh` (for Debug action), `vpl_evaluate.sh` (for Evaluate action). It is possible to only edit some of them. In your case, you only need to edit `vpl_evaluate.sh` All files submitted by the user are available in the environment. The `vpl_execution` file should write on standard output all information regarding the evaluation of the submitted code. All files submitted by the user are still available in the environment. There are several line formattings you should know about: - A line starting with `Grade :=>>` followed by a grade will set the grade of this evaluation. - A line starting with `Comment :=>>` will output a comment visible by the user. - `<|--` and `--|>` can be used to display multi-line comments. - Within multiline comments, lines starting with `-` will be displayed as headings, lines starting with `>` will be displayed as pre-formatted text. Dummy example for vpl_evaluate.sh contents: 
```text
  echo "echo Grade :=>> 100" > vpl_execution
  echo "echo Comment :=>> \"Well done!\"" >> vpl_execution
  chmod +x vpl_execution
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SSL_CTX_use_certificate_chain_file() fail: error:02001002:system library:fopen:No such file or directory
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath, It seems that your Certbot adds a ".001" to the name of the domain leading to an incorrect directory name and incorrect symbolic link. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SSL_CTX_use_certificate_chain_file() fail: error:02001002:system library:fopen:No such file or directory
ResponsesInList.Text: HI Visvanath. Notice that if you want to use VPL and Apache at the same machine and Apache is using Certbot to get the SSL certificates the correct way to install VPL is to indicate that you already have certificates and using symbolic links or the SSL_CERT_FILE and SSL_KEY_FILE parameters to allow VPL to get access to the certificates got by Apache. I guess that if you are getting two different certificates for the same HOSTFQDN the Certbot generates two different directories. If you are using Apache on the default ports HTTP:80/HTTPS:443 you must set VPL on two different ports g.e. HTTP:8080/HTTPS:8081. You can also remove the HTTP port from VPL. https://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/documentation/vpl-jail-system-2.7.0/configuration.html#ssl-cert-file Best regards, Juan Carlos.

```text
HNAME=pythonml.site


systemctl stop vpl-jail-system


certbot certonly --standalone --preferred-challenges http -d $HNAME
```

```text
systemctl start vpl-jail-system
```

ResponsesInList.Title: tip: VPL behind nginx reverse-proxy and "URL path not found"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I have been struggling for days trying to make our vpl jail server work behind an nginx reverse proxy. Everytime I tried to compile and run a program inside the vpl module in Moodle, I got no console displaying and a logged message " URL path not found" in syslog. When I traced connections to the vpl server, I could see that the Moodle server correctly sent the piece of code and all relevant data to the vpl server, but the Websocket connection from the browser to monitor the execution failed. Eventually, I had a look into the source code of the vpl server and discovered that this error message is thrown when vpl is called using a plain http request that do not match robots.txt or favicon.ico. Websocket requests are handled by another part of the code. So, I managed to find why vpl did not consider calls to the monitor as WS requests. It seems that a specific header is used to check if a request is a plain http or WS request. After Qwanting (like Googling, but using Qwant), I found two lines I had to add to my nginx site configuration file to make it proxy requests as WS requests: proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade; proxy_set_header Connection "upgrade"; Now, everything is working smoothly. BTW , I was previously using HAProxy as reverse proxy and it correctly handled ws connections without any further configuration. I hope this will be helpful to other people...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  No execution server available: - Error after various upgrades
ResponsesInList.Text: Notice that in the "Check execution servers" there is a column "Last error info" and another "Last error date". The execution server rejects a task if the memory requested is greater than the memory available in the server or greater than the MAXMEMORY parameter value (set in the execution server configuration). To avoid the problem, the "Maximum memory used" parameter in the site administration vpl plugin must be set to a value equal or lower than the MAXMEMORY in the execution server configuration and the available memory in your execution server. The line with "Memory requested 2097152000" shows a strange number of bytes. It seems that your installation has a very high "Maximum default memory used" value (site administration vpl plugin setting) and a low MAXMEMORY in the execution server configuration. Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:  No execution server available: - Error after various upgrades

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where are the output files are located?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Acqua Alta, at this moment there is no way to retrieve files created by the code of the students, really you can not get any files from the execution environment. But if you want to check the existence and content of files created by the student code you can use the features of the test cases to check it. For example, to check the existence of a file after a given test, you can: 1- Write a script to check the file's existence and its content. 2- Add a test case that runs the script. The test case after the case that creates the student file. 
```text
Case =
 Checks file content


program to run =
 check_file.sh


program arguments =
 student_file.txt correct_file.txt


Fail message =
 The file created does not exist or does not have the expected content


output =
 "OK"
```
 The script "check_file.sh" that checks the student's files. Notice: first parameter student file, second correct file. 
```text
#!/bin/bash


if 
[ -f  "$1" ]

then

    diff "$1" "$2" >& /dev/null
    
if 
[ "$?" == "0" ]
    
then

	echo "OK"
    
else

        echo "Differ"
    
fi


else

    echo "The file $1 does not exists"
```
 fi Note: the script and the correct files must be in the execution files and in "files to keep when running" Best regards, Juan Carlos.

A POST HTTP request commonly contents a header parameter that indicates the size of the payload. This error shows that the size of the payload found differs from the size indicated in the header parameter. In this case, there is no header parameter. It seems that something (between the Browser and the Moodle server ) is removing the header with the payload size. I don't know the reason. But I would check the following: - The PC has a virus. - You are using a buggy proxy. - You are using a buggy antivirus. - You are not using HTTPS connections.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to limit the number of evaluations?
ResponsesInList.Text: I will try to answer your three questions. Q1) Limiting the execution time for each test case. A1) At this moment you cannot set a different run-time limit for each test case. The default test program set a run-time limit equals to the total run-time limit divided by the number of test cases. The run-time limit can be set in the "Maximum execution resources limits" option. Q2) How can we limit the number of evaluations/submissions? A2) The number of evaluations or submissions cannot be limited. You can only penalize each evaluation. Q3) how to export the highest grade among all submissions like in CMS. A3) You cannot get the highest grade of each user, only the grade of the last submission. You can export the activity grades from the grade book of Moodle. Notice that VPL is not developed to support programming contest.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: VPL Not Secure
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Ricardo, At this moment, who configure to use http or https are the Moodle administrator by setting the plugin configuration and using HTTP or https at the "Execution servers list" and the teachers with privileges setting the local server list. Also the execution server administrator can control the access to the server by configuring the vpl-jail-service. Notice also that by default if your Moodle server use HTTP connection the browser will use not cyphered WebSocket connections with the execution server. Parameters at /etc/vpl/vpl-jail-system.conf you can use to control the access to your execution server: PORT : Sets the server port number for http and ws. Default 80. If you change this port only users that know the port number can access using HTTP to your server. In a future version, this access can be removed. e.g. http://servername:34377 URLPATH : Represents the PATH expected in execution requests. It acts as a password, if the URL PATH in the execution request does not match, the request is rejected. By default "/". If you set it only Moodle server that uses this URLPATH can use the service. e.g. http(s)://servername/PASS TASK_ONLY_FROM : IPs or networks (type A, B or C ) from which execution requests are accepted. You can set multiple separated by spaces. This parameter only affects Moodle servers, access from clients (browsers) is done using frugal tickets. If this property is not set the server will accept requests from any machine that set the correct URLPATH. Default not set. Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Test case from text file
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello. Ron Viner. I guess that you need (required) to use the standard input to give the data to the student's program. You can resolve this need with this approach: 1) Create aÂ  script "inputFile.sh" to pass the file to use as standard input to the student's program. 
```text
#!/bin/bash


read filename


if [Â  ! -f "$filename" ] ; then


Â  Â  echo "Error: file $filename not found"


else


Â  Â  # Runs student's program with $filename as standard input


Â  Â  ./vpl_test <$filename


fi
```
 Remember to mark "inputFile.sh" as "file to keep when running". To have the script available at testing time. 2) You must add to each test case at vpl_evaluate.cases file the following: program to run = ./inputFile.sh Example: 
```text
Case = Test file input


Program to run = ./inputFile.sh


input = data1.txt


output = "Expeted result"
```
 Important: VPL is not ready to evaluate based on the code runtime. VPL does not use a queued execution leading to the possibility that some tasks run in the same execution server at the same time. To palliate this problem the teacher, after all, can reevaluate all the student submissions using a dedicated jail server. In this situation, the evaluation tasks will be run one by one. Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Is there a way to have more that one VPL server to serve the users for load balancing and redundancy ? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Clustering VPL server
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not an expert in load balancing configuration but I think that with the network architecture of VPL it may be difficult to use an "execution server" load balancer. Notice that the execution process takes different steps and requires different network connections that need to be established with the same server in the cluster. For example, the evaluation process takes these steps. 1) A user launches an evaluation process. e.g. the user clicks evaluate button. 2) The browser sends a request ( AJAX / JSON ) to the Moodle server. 3) The Moodle server selects an execution server (with retries) and sends the task to an execution server (HTTP/XMLRPC). The execution server generates different security tokens as a response to de request. The task start. 4) The Moodle server responds to the Browser request with information with the "execution server URL " and the security tokens. 5) The browser connects with the execution server using the URL+security token and the "WebSocket" protocol to monitor the task. 6) When the task end, the monitor sends a request (AJAX/JSON) to the Moodle server to retrieve the task report/result. 8) The Moodle server request the "execution server" the task result (HTTP/XMLRPC) with the security token, save it and return the result to the browser. 9) The browser shows the result.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New Virtual Programming Lab (VPL) module
ResponsesInList.Text:
Dear Edizon, The output of the tests may be check in different ways: numbers, text, exact text, and regular expressions (see down for more details). If you want to allow answers that mix text and numbers it may be better to use a regular expression. e.g. 
```text
output = /\s*10.0\s*$/
```
 This expression will accept all programs that its output ends with 10.0, allowing spaces, tabs and nl around. Types of tests checks Numbers : only numbers are written. Only numbers are checked out, the rest of the text is ignored. The real numbers are checked with tolerance example: 
```text
output = 4


5 6.8
```
 Text : Only words are checked, the comparison is case-insensitive and the other characters are ignored. example: 
```text
output = lemon orange


apple
```
 Exact text : The text is enclosed in double-quotes. example: 
```text
output = "lemon orange


apple"
```
 Regular Expressions : It begins with / and ends with / and optionally one or several modifiers. The format is similar to JavaScript literal, but POSIX regex is used. example: 
```text
output = /lemon|orange|apple/i
```
 Best regards, Juan Carlos.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Support for other programming languages
ResponsesInList.Text: Q1 Wanted to know how I can add unavailable languages like Ruby or Oracle db. A1 You can install the compiler/interpreter into your execution server and write an execution script. You can know the available languages by creating a file with ".all" extension and running it. Due that VPL is a stateless execution system, may be difficult to develop scripts to execute Oracle queries inside VPL due to the need of keeping Oracle security/passwords and its and own users. Q2 Can I even evaluate multiple languages in a single program. Is creating a VM the correct way to execute it? A2 The I/O test system is independent of the programming language. The system detects the language used based on the filename extensiÃ³n. If you want the student to write a program using a mix of languages you need to write your own scripts. Q3 Can I create evaluation scripts directly in the plugin to achieve the same or web services would be a solution. A3 Yes, you can customize the system. But notice that all executions will be done in the execution server. Q4 Any instruction documentation would be great. A4 Sorry for the poor documentation. You may search for similar questions in the old forum. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=154988 Best regards, Juan Carlos.

Hi Juan Carlos! Thanks for the fast reply! It turned out to be very helpful, since you've forced me to prepare a reproducible example. Then I refactored the actual Scala sample and saw that the problem was not the network but some misleading " java .lang.OutOfMemoryError: unable to create new native thread", which doesn't indicate a memory issue but has to do with getting new threads from the operating system.
```text
. common_script.sh


check_program scala


check_program scalac


APP=${VPL_SUBFILE0%.*}


scalac $VPL_SUBFILE0


cat common_script.sh > vpl_execution


echo "scala -nocompdaemon -classpath ./ $APP" >> vpl_execution


chmod +x vpl_execution
```
 Compared to your current default script it assumes that the scala code is an application like follows: 
```text
object MyApp extends App {


...


}
```
 This is way more common than writing scripts. The file, however, has to have the same name as the object defined in it (in our case "MyApp.scala", which is the same as in Java). Then this file is compiled and the app started. Probably you might use this as a new default script! Regards, Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New Virtual Programming Lab (VPL) module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Oleg, The use of automatic program testing is one of the main target of VPL. The libraries can be used in two ways: as source codeÂ  files of a VPL's activity, (they must be added in the â€œexecution filesâ€ configuration page , better in a VPL activity shared as â€œbased onâ€), or as software installed in every jail-servers you use. To use one assignment for different tasks you can use â€œVariationsâ€.Â  The variations define sets of different requirements for an assignment.Â  Each student will be randomly assigned a variation. Each variation has an identification code and a description. The variation description is shown to the students with the assignment description. The identification code is reported in the vpl_enviroment.sh , so it can be used in the script files (vpl_execution.sh, vpl_evaluation.sh) to do different actions depending on it. Another way to control different task for one assignment may be to write a complex script able to detect the type of assignment submitted by checking , by example,the file names submitted by the student. Best regards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New Virtual Programming Lab (VPL) module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Oee, Iâ€™ll try to answer your questions Q1.Â Â Â  What is meant by server? server where moodle is running? Or server where jail service is running?Â  I am running jail server on separate machine and I configured firewall settings. A1. In this paragraph â€œserverâ€ refers to â€œjail serverâ€. Q2.Â Â Â  What is meant by "/RPC"? A2. The requests from the â€œmoodle serverâ€ to the â€œJail serverâ€ use XMLRPC protocol and â€œ/RPCâ€ is the default path in the URL of a XMLRPC service. Omitting the â€œ-uriâ€ parameter is equivalent to use â€œ-uri /RPCâ€ Q3.Â Â  Do I need a value for "/path"? What is it? A3. To simplify the configuration you may use â€œ-uri /â€ then you can use as URL of your â€œjail serverâ€ http://hostname:port Q4.Â  What is value for "-uri" argument? A4. Well, â€œuriâ€ is the parameter name for the â€œpathâ€ in the URL to the â€œjail serverâ€ (http://hostname:port/path) Q5. I didn't set any *.sh file, do i need them even I want to run each submission alone? A5. The VPL versions <=1.3 always need to setup â€œvpl_run.shâ€ file orÂ  â€œvpl_evaluate.shâ€Â  file to run programs. You may use the "based on" option to reduce the script files setting. The VPL 1.4 version will be loaded with default scripts for common programming languages as C, C++, Java, C#, etc. A basic file for â€œvpl_run.shâ€ or â€œvpl_evaluate.shâ€ for Java may looks like this: =========================== #!/bin/bash #load VPL environment vars . vpl_environment.sh #reset LC_ALL export LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 #Set path to JDK PATH=$PATH:/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.6.0-openjdk/bin #compile echo "The first file/class must have the Main method" javac -J-Xmx64m *.java NAME=$(basename $VPL_SUBFILE0 .java) if [ -f $NAME.class ] ; then echo "#!/bin/bash" >> vpl_execution echo "export LC_ALL=en_US.utf8" >> vpl_execution echo "PATH=\$PATH:/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.6.0-openjdk/bin" >> vpl_execution echo "java -Xmx64M -enableassertions $NAME" >> vpl_execution chmod +x vpl_execution else echo "No compiled or error in file name" fi =========================== Examples of /etc/xinetd.d/vpl-xmlrpc-jail file: 1) ==================================== service vpl-xmlrpc-jail { â€¦ port = 8080 # no server_args parameter â€¦ } ===================================== If the server name is â€œjail1.uni.eduâ€ then the URL to access the service in the â€œjail serverâ€ would be http://jail1.uni.edu:8080/RPC 2) ==================================== service vpl-xmlrpc-jail { â€¦ port = 52000 server_args = -uri / â€¦ } ===================================== If the server name is â€œjail1.uni.eduâ€ then the URL to access the service in the â€œjail serverâ€ would be http://jail1.uni.edu:52000 Hope that this helps you. Best regards.

ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Udara, Iâ€™ll try to respond to your questions but not in the order you ask them. ========== Question 1) what should I do with *.sh files, where should I create those? Answer 1) There are three types of execution you can set for an activity: â€œrunâ€, â€œdebugâ€ and â€œevaluateâ€. The â€œrunâ€ and â€œdebugâ€ actions do an online execution in a console (the console is part of the applet editor). The â€œevaluateâ€ action does an offline execution and its output is saved as part of the submission. Each action (â€œrunâ€, â€œdebugâ€ and â€œevaluateâ€) has its own script: vpl_run.sh, vpl_debug.sh and vpl_evalaute.sh.Â  The goal of these scripts is generate a file named â€œvpl_executionâ€. This file must be a binary executable or a script and if it exists, after running the action script, it will be run. You may set your script files (vpl_run.sh, vpl_debug.sh and vpl_evalaute.sh) by â€œupdatingâ€ your VPL activity and then selecting â€œexecutionâ€. You can't set scripts when you are creating a new VPL activity. ========== Question 2) I got the message stating "not executed" Answer 2) This message say that your script linked to the action you request do not generate a file â€œvpl_executionâ€. ========== Question 3) What is the purpose of ACodeEditor? how can i use it? Answer 3) Really, to run VPL you donâ€™t need the source files of â€œACodeEditorâ€, the applet code editor. The VPL module already has the â€œACodeEditorâ€ compiled.Â  The source files of â€œACodeEditorâ€ are at the download page of the VPL site because it is Open Source as the rest of VPL. ========== The log file you attach says that your Jail server is running OK, so far, but at your post you say that you are trying to run a C program and the file you use was â€œhello.javaâ€. To populate the script files, you can use the content I have suggested in other messages of the forum. Best regards.

Although we have made some progress in this development, we have not achieved a full functional version and does not seem to be near. I will try to answer your questions about java output terminal. A 1. At this moment, you cannot save the program output to a file which is stored in the Moodle server. To get something similar, you must write, in the configuration file "vpl_evaluate.sh", the following: ---------------------------- #/bin/sh . vpl_run.sh ---------------------------- this will make that when you push "evaluate" the program output will be saved as the result of the automatic evaluation. "execution files" are the scripts and files that will be send, with the student's files, to in the jail server.Â  If you don't check it in "Files to keep when running", all "execution files" will be removed before run vpl_execution. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New Virtual Programming Lab (VPL) module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jeremy, Thanks for the information about Stanford's CodingBat. VPL is a flexible tool and useful for many uses. If you want to get activities similar to those of CodingBat with VPL, for example: an activity that asks for the sum of two integers, follow these steps: 1) Add a new VPL activity and write there the problem description. 2) Go to â€œVPL administration>Requested filesâ€ and add the file Sum2.java 3) Edit and write the following code in Sum2.java ----------------------- public class Sum2 { public static int sum2 (int a, int b) { / / Add here your solution } } ------------------------- This will be the initial content file for the student 4) Go to â€œVPL administration> Advanced settings > Execution filesâ€ and add a file called LoadSum2.java 5) Edit and write the following code in LoadSum2.java import java.util.Scanner; public class LoadSum2 { public static void main (String [] args) { Scanner input = new Scanner (System.in) ; int a = input.nextInt (); int b = input.nextInt (); System.out.println (Sum2.sum2 (a, b)); } } This code will pass test cases to the studentâ€™s code. 6) Go to â€œVPL administration> Test casesâ€ and write as example two cases: CaseÂ  = Case 1 input = 1 2 output = 3 Case = Case 2 input = 5Â  -1 output = 4 7) Finally, go to the â€œVPL administration> Execution optionsâ€ and set Run and Evaluate to Yes. Now you have a VPL activity with functionalities similar to CodingBat. I donâ€™t know if these steps are too complex but once you do one of these activities it is easy to do a lot of them. Best regards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to run Java programs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Pragati, Your shell script seems to be correct, the problem is due to theÂ  reserve of 512Mb of memory for the Java heap. If you set this memory for the heap then you will need a memory limit great than 512M (the execution of the Java VM needs much more). You should be aware that if you do not specify a value for the limit of memory to use in an activity, it takes the default value set in the global configuration of the module (Home â–º Site administration â–º Plugins â–º Activity modules â–º Virtual programming lab) (the default value is 256MiB) . ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New Virtual Programming Lab (VPL) module
ResponsesInList.Text: I will try to answer all your questions: 1) â€œIs it safe to run jail2.0 and jail1.2 together in the same system?â€ During the development of jail 2.0 we never consider this scenery. It may be possible, but I think it requires a lot of work. 2) "Can be used directories on the required files, execution files or the files submitted by students" what does it actually mean? The module and the jail server are ready to use files in a directory structure but in this first feature release, this is only possible at the editor. You can't upload files to a directory without the editor. 3) "... installed a lot of GUI-related packages. Can this be avoided?" The new jail server can run programs with GUI. If you don't use it you can remove it from your jail server, but I think that freeing 1 GB of disk space don't pay the work. 4) "... Are these meant only for saving students the hassle of installing necessary stuff on their computers?" In general our students are free to use any IDE, but in the first contact they may prefer an easy to use development tool with few options (save/run/debug/evaluate). They also can work in any PC with a browser and get the bonus of using the evaluation feature. On the other hand they lost the autocomplete features and a good debugger of an IDE. On the other hand, if the student use the editor, the teacher can get a better picture of the students' work (the system keeps previous submissions). The teacher can easily answer questions about a student work without the need of download or run any code in their machine. The teacher can also run easily GUI works as part of the evaluation. We also use the system to do exams under controlled conditions, in these cases the use of the editor is required. In short, many students and teachers use the editor when the job is small or even medium, but this is not commonly mandatory. Best regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Having problem creating user vpl_evaluate.sh script
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, it's possible, but not recommended. The load of execution in the jail server can interfere in the execution of Moodle. The security is another problem that can arise. If you have enough hardware assigned to the moodle server you can install Virtualbox in your virtual machine (yes, a virtual machine into a virtual machine) and install there the jail server. You must be aware of three things: 1) Your jail server (service) must have assigned two ports differents than defaults (80 and 443) for example 52000 and 52001. Change properly the configuration file. 2) Your jail server ports must be accessible from internet (not only from your Moodle server). You can use NAT port forwarding if using in VirtualBox 3) Use the correct URL (eg http://servername:port/path) in the general plugin configuration in the Moodle server Best regards Juan Carlos

The steps for installation and configuration are: Install an Ubuntu server as clean as possible Download the latest version of the software (vpl-jail-system) with the command 
```text
wget 
http://vpl.dis.ulpgc.es/releases/vpl_jail_system-2.0.2.tar.gz
```
 Unzip and install the vpl-jail-system 
```text
tar -xvf vpl_jail_system-latest.tar.gz



         cd vpl_jail_system-*



         sudo ./install-vpl-sh
```
 Follow the instructions and wait for the necessary downloads. The installation script will try to install the development software commonly used, but you may need to install some other by hand. Stop the service with the command `sudo service vpl-jail-system stop` Edit the file /etc/vpl/vpl-jail-system.conf. Set the URLPATH that will be used as key in connections with your execution server Start the service `sudo service vpl-jail-system start`
